welcomeMessage: Welcome, **@chefgs**, I'm your Copilot and I'm here to help you get things done faster. You can also [start an inline chat session](command:workbench.action.quickchat.launchInlineChat).

I'm powered by AI, so surprises and mistakes are possible. Make sure to verify any generated code or suggestions, and [share feedback](https://aka.ms/microsoft/vscode-copilot-release) so that we can learn and improve. Check out the [Copilot documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/getting-started-chat) to learn more.

agent.description: Ask Copilot or type / for commands

metadata.helpTextPrefix: You can ask me general programming questions, or chat with the following participants which have specialized expertise and can perform actions:
metadata.helpTextVariablesPrefix: You can also help me understand your question by using the following variables to give me extra context:

helpTextPostfix.value:
To have a great conversation, ask me questions as if I was a real programmer:

* **Show me the code** you want to talk about by having the files open and selecting the most important lines.
* **Make refinements** by asking me follow-up questions, adding clarifications, providing errors, etc.
* **Review my suggested code** and tell me about issues or improvements, so I can iterate on it.

You can also ask me questions about your editor selection by [starting an inline chat session](command:inlineChat.start).

Learn more about [GitHub Copilot](https://docs.github.com/copilot/using-github-copilot/getting-started-with-github-copilot?tool=vscode&utm_source=editor&utm_medium=chat-panel&utm_campaign=2024q3-em-MSFT-getstarted) in [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/overview).

command.name: explain
command.description: Explain how the code in your active editor works

response.value:
Certainly! The provided shell script is designed to automate the installation of Terraform on an Ubuntu system. Terraform is an open-source infrastructure as code software tool created by HashiCorp. Here's a step-by-step explanation of what each part of the script does:

1. **Shebang and Comments**:
   The script begins with a shebang (`#!/bin/bash`), which tells the system to execute the script using the Bash shell. Following this, there are comments explaining the purpose of the script and providing a reference to the official Terraform installation documentation.

2. **System Update and Prerequisites Installation**:
   The command `sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y gnupg software-properties-common` updates the package lists for upgrades and installs [`gnupg`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A4%2C%22character%22%3A47%7D%7D%5D%2C%229ef42955-5e13-4d63-abc7-151db94f6693%22%5D "Go to definition") and `software-properties-common`. [`gnupg`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A4%2C%22character%22%3A47%7D%7D%5D%2C%229ef42955-5e13-4d63-abc7-151db94f6693%22%5D "Go to definition") is needed for handling encryption keys, and `software-properties-common` provides an abstraction of the used apt repositories.

3. **Adding HashiCorp GPG Key**:
   The script uses [`wget`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A6%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%7D%5D%2C%229ef42955-5e13-4d63-abc7-151db94f6693%22%5D "Go to definition") to download the HashiCorp GPG key and pipes it through `gpg --dearmor` to convert it into a format suitable for apt. The resulting key is then stored in `/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg` using `sudo tee`.

4. **Verifying the GPG Key**:
   The command `gpg --no-default-keyring --keyring /usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg --fingerprint` verifies the fingerprint of the imported GPG key to ensure its authenticity.

5. **Adding HashiCorp Repository**:
   The script adds the HashiCorp repository to the system's list of apt sources. It constructs a new repository entry with the line `deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg] https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com $(lsb_release -cs) main` and writes it to `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/hashicorp.list`. The `$(lsb_release -cs)` command dynamically inserts the codename of the Ubuntu release.

6. **Updating Package Lists**:
   The command `sudo apt update` updates the package lists to include the newly added HashiCorp repository.

7. **Installing Terraform**:
   The script installs Terraform using `sudo apt-get install terraform -y`. The `-y` flag automatically confirms the installation prompts.

8. **Verifying Installation**:
   Finally, the script runs `terraform -help` to display the help message of Terraform, confirming that the installation was successful.

This script is a convenient way to ensure that Terraform is installed correctly and securely on an Ubuntu system by automating the necessary steps.

command.name: explain
command.description: Explain how the code in your active editor works

response.value:
Certainly! The provided shell script is designed to automate the installation of Terraform on an Ubuntu system. Terraform is an open-source infrastructure as code software tool created by HashiCorp. Here's a detailed explanation of what each part of the script does:

The script begins with a shebang (`#!/bin/bash`), which tells the system to execute the script using the Bash shell. Following this, there are comments explaining the purpose of the script and providing a reference to the official Terraform installation documentation.

The first command, `sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y gnupg software-properties-common`, updates the package lists for upgrades and installs [`gnupg`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A4%2C%22character%22%3A47%7D%7D%5D%2C%222846a740-7e65-4052-acba-3aba06272660%22%5D "Go to definition") and `software-properties-common`. [`gnupg`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A4%2C%22character%22%3A47%7D%7D%5D%2C%222846a740-7e65-4052-acba-3aba06272660%22%5D "Go to definition") is needed for handling encryption keys, and `software-properties-common` provides an abstraction of the used apt repositories.

Next, the script uses [`wget`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-terraform.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A6%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%7D%5D%2C%222846a740-7e65-4052-acba-3aba06272660%22%5D "Go to definition") to download the HashiCorp GPG key and pipes it through `gpg --dearmor` to convert it into a format suitable for apt. The resulting key is then stored in `/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg` using `sudo tee`. This step ensures that the system can verify the authenticity of packages downloaded from the HashiCorp repository.

The command `gpg --no-default-keyring --keyring /usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg --fingerprint` verifies the fingerprint of the imported GPG key to ensure its authenticity. This is a security measure to confirm that the key is legitimate and has not been tampered with.

The script then adds the HashiCorp repository to the system's list of apt sources. It constructs a new repository entry with the line `deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/hashicorp-archive-keyring.gpg] https://apt.releases.hashicorp.com $(lsb_release -cs) main` and writes it to `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/hashicorp.list`. The `$(lsb_release -cs)` command dynamically inserts the codename of the Ubuntu release, ensuring compatibility with the specific version of Ubuntu being used.

After adding the repository, the command `sudo apt update` updates the package lists to include the newly added HashiCorp repository. This step is necessary to make the system aware of the new source of packages.

The script then installs Terraform using `sudo apt-get install terraform -y`. The `-y` flag automatically confirms the installation prompts, making the process non-interactive and suitable for automation.

Finally, the script runs `terraform -help` to display the help message of Terraform, confirming that the installation was successful. This step serves as a quick verification that Terraform is correctly installed and ready to use.

Overall, this script is a convenient way to ensure that Terraform is installed correctly and securely on an Ubuntu system by automating the necessary steps.

command.name: explain
command.description: Explain how the code in your active editor works

response.value:
Certainly! The provided shell script is designed to automate the installation and initial setup of Jenkins on an Ubuntu system. Jenkins is an open-source automation server that helps automate parts of the software development process, such as building, testing, and deploying code.

The script begins by adding the Jenkins apt repository to the system's list of package sources. This is done using the [`echo`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A13%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%7D%5D%2C%2281f0de6b-7213-4cd9-92ea-98d925a2240c%22%5D "Go to definition") command to create a new repository entry with the line `deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/jenkins-keyring.asc] https://pkg.jenkins.io/debian binary/`. This line is then piped into `sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/jenkins.list`, which writes it to a new file in the `/etc/apt/sources.list.d/` directory. The `> /dev/null` part ensures that the output of the [`tee`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A13%2C%22character%22%3A106%7D%7D%5D%2C%2281f0de6b-7213-4cd9-92ea-98d925a2240c%22%5D "Go to definition") command is not displayed on the terminal.

Next, the script updates the package lists using `sudo apt update -y`. This command refreshes the list of available packages and their versions, ensuring that the system is aware of the latest versions of the software available from the newly added Jenkins repository.

The script then proceeds to install Jenkins with the command `sudo apt install jenkins -y`. The `-y` flag automatically confirms the installation prompts, making the process non-interactive and suitable for automation.

After installing Jenkins, the script starts the Jenkins service using `sudo systemctl start jenkins` and enables it to start automatically on system boot with `sudo systemctl enable jenkins`. This ensures that Jenkins is running and will continue to run even after the system is restarted.

The script also configures the firewall to allow traffic on port 8080, which is the default port Jenkins uses. This is done with the command `sudo ufw allow 8080`. Additionally, it allows OpenSSH traffic with `sudo ufw allow OpenSSH` and then enables the firewall with `sudo ufw enable`. These commands ensure that Jenkins can be accessed remotely and that the system remains secure.

Finally, the script outputs a message indicating that the Jenkins installation is complete and displays the initial admin password. The initial admin password is required to unlock Jenkins during the first setup. The password is stored in a file located at `/var/lib/jenkins/secrets/initialAdminPassword`, and the script uses `sudo cat` to display its contents.

Overall, this script provides a convenient and automated way to install Jenkins, start its service, configure the firewall, and retrieve the initial admin password, making it easier to get Jenkins up and running on an Ubuntu system.

message.text: add java_home env variable in script

parts.text: add java_home env variable in script

response.value:
To add the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable to the script, you need to determine the path to the Java installation. Typically, Jenkins requires Java, so you should ensure Java is installed and then set the `JAVA_HOME` variable accordingly.

Here's the updated script with the addition of setting the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable:

```shell
# Add Jenkins apt repository
echo deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/jenkins-keyring.asc] https://pkg.jenkins.io/debian binary/ | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/jenkins.list > /dev/null

# Update package lists
sudo apt update -y

# Install Java (if not already installed)
sudo apt install openjdk-11-jdk -y

# Set JAVA_HOME environment variable
echo "export JAVA_HOME=$(dirname $(dirname $(readlink -f $(which java))))" | sudo tee -a /etc/profile
source /etc/profile

# Install Jenkins
sudo apt install jenkins -y

# Start and enable Jenkins service
sudo systemctl enable jenkins
sudo systemctl start jenkins

# Allow Jenkins through firewall (if enabled)
sudo ufw allow 8080
sudo ufw allow OpenSSH
sudo ufw enable

# Output Jenkins initial password
echo "Jenkins Installation completed."
echo "Initial admin password:"
sudo cat /var/lib/jenkins/secrets/initialAdminPassword
```

### Explanation:
1. **Install Java**: The script installs OpenJDK 11 using `sudo apt install openjdk-11-jdk -y`.
2. **Set `JAVA_HOME`**: The script sets the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable by determining the path to the Java installation and appending it to `/etc/profile`. This ensures that the `JAVA_HOME` variable is set system-wide.
3. **Source `/etc/profile`**: The script sources `/etc/profile` to apply the changes immediately.

This ensures that the `JAVA_HOME` environment variable is set correctly and available for Jenkins and other applications that might need it.

variables.name: terminalSelection
variables.value:
The active terminal's selection:

"systemd" is not running in this container due to its overhead.
Use the "service" command to start services instead. e.g.:

response.value:
It looks like you're running into an issue where `systemd` is not available in your container environment, and you need to use the [`service`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A27%7D%7D%5D%2C%22f789a477-4261-407f-850b-baf1d2a009a2%22%5D "Go to definition") command instead to manage services like Jenkins. Let's modify your script to use the [`service`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A27%7D%7D%5D%2C%22f789a477-4261-407f-850b-baf1d2a009a2%22%5D "Go to definition") command for starting and enabling Jenkins.

Here's the updated script:

```shell
# Add Jenkins apt repository
echo deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/jenkins-keyring.asc] https://pkg.jenkins.io/debian binary/ | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/jenkins.list > /dev/null

# Update package lists
sudo apt update -y

# Install Jenkins
sudo apt install jenkins -y

# Start Jenkins service
sudo service jenkins start

# Enable Jenkins service to start on boot
sudo service jenkins enable

# Wait for Jenkins to start
sleep 60

# Output Jenkins initial password
echo "Jenkins Installation completed."

echo "Initial admin password:"
sudo cat /var/lib/jenkins

vulnerabilities.title: hardcoded-credentials
vulnerabilities.description: Embedding credentials in source code risks unauthorized access

response.value:
crets/initialAdminPassword
```

### Explanation of Changes:
1. **Starting Jenkins Service**: Replaced `sudo systemctl start jenkins` with `sudo service jenkins start`.
2. **Enabling Jenkins Service**: Replaced `sudo systemctl enable jenkins` with `sudo service jenkins enable`.

This should allow you to start and enable the Jenkins service in an environment where `systemd` is not available. If the [`service`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A27%7D%7D%5D%2C%22f789a477-4261-407f-850b-baf1d2a009a2%22%5D "Go to definition") command does not support the [`enable`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A12%7D%7D%5D%2C%22f789a477-4261-407f-850b-baf1d2a009a2%22%5D "Go to definition") option, you might need to manually configure the service to start on boot, depending on your container's init system.

message.text: how to check for systemd available in server

parts.text: how to check for systemd available in server

response.value:
To check if `systemd` is available on your server, you can use the following command:

```shell
pidof systemd
```

If `systemd` is running, this command will return the process ID of `systemd`. If `systemd` is not running, it will return nothing.

You can incorporate this check into your script to conditionally use [`systemctl`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A26%2C%22character%22%3A5%7D%7D%5D%2C%22d9130d83-6e32-4506-aef6-000aec622da2%22%5D "Go to definition") or [`service`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A27%7D%7D%5D%2C%22d9130d83-6e32-4506-aef6-000aec622da2%22%5D "Go to definition") based on the availability of `systemd`. Heres how you can modify your script:

```shell
# Add Jenkins apt repository
echo deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/jenkins-keyring.asc] https://pkg.jenkins.io/debian binary/ | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/jenkins.list > /dev/null

# Update package lists
sudo apt update -y

# Install Jenkins
sudo apt install jenkins -y

# Check if systemd is available
if pidof systemd > /dev/null; then
    # Start and enable Jenkins service using systemctl
    sudo systemctl enable jenkins
    sudo systemctl start jenkins
else
    # Start Jenkins service using service command
    sudo service jenkins start
    # Enable Jenkins service to start on boot (if applicable)
    sudo update-rc.d jenkins defaults
fi

# Wait for Jenkins to start
sleep 60

# Output Jenkins initial password
echo "Jenkins Installation completed."
echo "Initial admin password:"
sudo cat /var/lib/jenkins/secrets/initialAdminPassword
```

### Explanation:
1. **Check for `systemd`**: The script uses `pidof systemd` to check if `systemd` is running.
2. **Conditional Service Management**: Based on the availability of `systemd`, the script either uses [`systemctl`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A26%2C%22character%22%3A5%7D%7D%5D%2C%22d9130d83-6e32-4506-aef6-000aec622da2%22%5D "Go to definition") or [`service`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%22%22%2C%5B%7B%22uri%22%3A%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2Fworkspaces%2Finstall-cicd-tools%2Finstall-jenkins.sh%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%2C%22pos%22%3A%7B%22line%22%3A25%2C%22character%22%3A27%7D%7D%5D%2C%22d9130d83-6e32-4506-aef6-000aec622da2%22%5D "Go to definition") to start and enable Jenkins.
3. **Enable Jenkins on Boot**: If `systemd` is not available, the script uses `update-rc.d jenkins defaults` to enable Jenkins to start on boot.

This approach ensures that your script works correctly regardless of whether `systemd` is available on the server.

agent.name: GitHubCopilot

message.text: Create a script to install jenkins using image in an ubuntu instance

parts.text: Create a script to install jenkins using image in an ubuntu instance

response.value:
Certainly! Below is a script to install Jenkins using a Docker image on an Ubuntu instance. This script will install Docker, pull the Jenkins Docker image, and run Jenkins in a Docker container.

```shell
#!/bin/bash

# Update package lists
sudo apt update -y

# Install prerequisites
sudo apt install -y apt-transport-https ca-certificates curl software-properties-common

# Add Docker's official GPG key
curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | sudo apt-key add -

# Add Docker's official APT repository
sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu $(lsb_release -cs) stable"

# Update package lists again
sudo apt update -y

# Install Docker
sudo apt install -y docker-ce

# Start Docker service
sudo systemctl start docker
sudo systemctl enable docker

# Pull the official Jenkins Docker image
sudo docker pull jenkins/jenkins:lts

# Run Jenkins container
sudo docker run -d -p 8080:8080 -p 50000:50000 --name jenkins -v jenkins_home:/var/jenkins_home jenkins/jenkins:lts

# Wait for Jenkins to start
sleep 60

# Output Jenkins initial password
echo "Jenkins Installation completed."
echo "Initial admin password:"
sudo docker exec jenkins cat /var/jenkins_home/secrets/initialAdminPassword
```

### Explanation:
1. **Update Package Lists**: The script starts by updating the package lists using `sudo apt update -y`.
2. **Install Prerequisites**: It installs necessary packages for Docker installation.
3. **Add Docker GPG Key**: The script adds Docker's official GPG key.
4. **Add Docker Repository**: It adds Docker's official APT repository.
5. **Update Package Lists Again**: The script updates the package lists again to include the Docker repository.
6. **Install Docker**: It installs Docker using `sudo apt install -y docker-ce`.
7. **Start Docker Service**: The script starts and enables the Docker service.
8. **Pull Jenkins Docker Image**: It pulls the official Jenkins Docker image.
9. **Run Jenkins Container**: The script runs Jenkins in a Docker container, mapping ports 8080 and 50000 and using a named volume `jenkins_home` for persistent storage.
10. **Wait for Jenkins to Start**: It waits for 60 seconds to allow Jenkins to start.
11. **Output Jenkins Initial Password**: The script outputs the initial admin password required to unlock Jenkins.

This script provides a convenient way to install and run Jenkins using Docker on an Ubuntu instance.

metadata.sampleRequest: How do I view all files within a directory including sub-directories?

agent.name: terminal

slashCommands.name: explain
slashCommands.description: Explain something in the terminal
slashCommands.sampleRequest: Explain the last command

variables.name: terminalLastCommand
variables.value:
The active terminal's last run command:
The following is the last command run in the terminal:
sudo service docker status
It was run in the directory:
/workspaces/install-cicd-tools
It has the following output:
docker: unrecognized service

response.value:
It looks like the `docker` service is not recognized on your system. This could be due to Docker not being installed or the service name being incorrect. To check if Docker is installed, you can run:

```bash
docker --version
```

If Docker is not installed, you can install it using the following commands:

```bash
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y docker.io
```

After installation, start the Docker service and enable it to start on boot:

```bash
sudo systemctl start docker
sudo systemctl enable docker
```

Then, you can check the status of the Docker service with:

```bash
sudo systemctl status docker
```

If Docker is already installed but the service name is incorrect, try using `systemctl` instead of `service`:

```bash
sudo systemctl status docker
```
